snippet: Dee Rees, the writer and director of "Pariah," a film about a young lesbian living in Brooklyn, discusses her film in this video segment.
abstract: Dee Rees, the writer and director of "Pariah," a film about a young lesbian living in Brooklyn, discusses her film in this video segment.
lead_paragraph: While "Pariah" tells the coming-out story of a young African-American lesbian in Brooklyn, its director, Dee Rees, sought to make a film with broader themes. Ms. Rees, who received a Gotham Award this season for breakthrough director and a best director prize from the Black Film Critics Circle, sees her film as a story about identity and self-discovery. "Pariah," which stars Adepero Oduye, was a breakout hit at Sundance last year and finally made it to theaters last month. Reviewing the film for The Times, Stephen Holden called it "an acutely observed examination of strait-laced parents trying to deny a child's homosexuality while all the time knowing better."
